text: Think step by step Act as an **English grammar checker designer"Now the target users are C1-lev ESL L1 Cantonese speakers, causal and professional contexts.You need a full, exhaustive list of errors + minimal pairs the checker must always identify, and then indicate in the list that each of them is an error that eithera. A checker must flag and explain,b. A checker must only flag Provide a list of types of errors + minimal pairs,DO NOT ANALYSIS Below is a design-oriented list of error types plus minimal pairs for C1 Cantonese L1 users, marked as: (a) Checker must flag and explain (b) Checker must only flag Each minimal pair: first sentence is incorrect, second is correct. 1. Articles 1.1 Omission with singular countable nouns (a)Incorrect: I have meeting this afternoon.Correct: I have a meeting this afternoon. 1.2 Wrong definite vs zero article (generic vs specific) (a)Incorrect: The life is difficult in Hong Kong.Correct: Life is difficult in Hong Kong. 1.3 Overuse of definite article (a)Incorrect: The pollution is a big problem in the most cities.Correct: Pollution is a big problem in most cities. 1.4 A vs an (a)Incorrect: She is an university student.Correct: She is a university student. 1.5 Redundant article with proper nouns (a)Incorrect: I will travel to the Japan next month.Correct: I will travel to Japan next month. 2. Countable / uncountable nouns 2.1 Uncountable made plural (a)Incorrect: I need more informations about the project.Correct: I need more information about the project. 2.2 Wrong quantifier with uncountable (a)Incorrect: I don’t have many time this week.Correct: I don’t have much time this week. 2.3 Countable vs uncountable meaning shift (a)Incorrect: We bought many furnitures for the new office.Correct: We bought a lot of furniture for the new office. 3. Noun number and noun phrases 3.1 Missing plural -s after numbers (a)Incorrect: The company has over 200 employee.Correct: The company has over 200 employees. 3.2 Wrong of-structure with measures (a)Incorrect: We ordered three equipments for the lab.Correct: We ordered three pieces of equipment for the lab. 3.3 Inconsistent number within NP (a)Incorrect: These kind of problems are common.Correct: These kinds of problems are common. 4. Subject–verb agreement 4.1 Singular/plural mismatch (a)Incorrect: The results shows a clear trend.Correct: The results show a clear trend. 4.2 There is / there are (a)Incorrect: There is many reasons to move.Correct: There are many reasons to move. 4.3 Indefinite pronouns as subject (a)Incorrect: Everyone know the policy.Correct: Everyone knows the policy. 4.4 Agreement with complex noun phrases (a)Incorrect: The number of accidents have increased.Correct: The number of accidents has increased. 5. Tense and aspect 5.1 Present simple vs present continuous (a)Incorrect: I am knowing what you mean.Correct: I know what you mean. 5.2 Past simple vs present perfect (a)Incorrect: I have finished the report yesterday.Correct: I finished the report yesterday. 5.3 Overuse of present perfect for finished past with time adverbial (a)Incorrect: We have met last week.Correct: We met last week. 5.4 Past perfect sequence (a)Incorrect: When I arrived, he left already.Correct: When I arrived, he had already left. 5.5 Will vs be going to for plans (b)Incorrect: I will meet him tonight (for a fixed, arranged plan).Correct: I am going to meet him tonight. 5.6 Habitual “will” misuse (a)Incorrect: In Hong Kong, people will eat out a lot.Correct: In Hong Kong, people eat out a lot. 6. Modal verbs 6.1 To-infinitive after modals (a)Incorrect: We must to finish this today.Correct: We must finish this today. 6.2 Double modals (a)Incorrect: It might can be delayed.Correct: It might be delayed. 6.3 Politeness gradation in requests (b)Incorrect: You must send me the file now.Correct: Could you please send me the file now? 6.4 Misuse of should / must (strength of obligation) (b)Incorrect: You must reply if you have time.Correct: You should reply if you have time. 7. Conditionals 7.1 If + will in condition clause (a)Incorrect: If it will rain, we will cancel the event.Correct: If it rains, we will cancel the event. 7.2 Second conditional verb form (a)Incorrect: If I will have time, I would join.Correct: If I had time, I would join. 7.3 Third conditional verb form (a)Incorrect: If I knew earlier, I would have help you.Correct: If I had known earlier, I would have helped you. 7.4 Mixed conditional mismatch (b)Incorrect: If I studied harder, I would have a better job now.Correct: If I had studied harder, I would have a better job now. 8. Gerunds and infinitives 8.1 Verb + gerund vs infinitive selection (a)Incorrect: I suggested to postpone the meeting.Correct: I suggested postponing the meeting. 8.2 Preposition + gerund (a)Incorrect: He is interested to learn French.Correct: He is interested in learning French. 8.3 Object + gerund/infinitive (a)Incorrect: They made me to feel welcome.Correct: They made me feel welcome. 9. Prepositions 9.1 Time prepositions (in/on/at) (a)Incorrect: We will meet in Friday.Correct: We will meet on Friday. 9.2 Place prepositions (in/at/on) (a)Incorrect: I will wait you at the bus.Correct: I will wait for you on the bus. 9.3 Verb + preposition collocations (a)Incorrect: It depends of the situation.Correct: It depends on the situation. 9.4 Adjective + preposition collocations (a)Incorrect: She is similar with her sister.Correct: She is similar to her sister. 9.5 Omission of preposition (a)Incorrect: I will contact you next week.Correct: I will contact you again next week. (for missing linking preposition, use clearer pair)Incorrect: I am responsible this project.Correct: I am responsible for this project. 9.6 Overuse of to after explain, discuss, mention (a)Incorrect: We discussed about the budget.Correct: We discussed the budget. 10. Pronouns 10.1 Subject vs object case (a)Incorrect: Him and I will join the call.Correct: He and I will join the call. 10.2 Pronoun reference clarity (a)Incorrect: When John met Peter, he was angry.Correct: When John met Peter, John was angry. 10.3 It vs they for objects (a)Incorrect: I bought a new phone. They is very good.Correct: I bought a new phone. It is very good. 10.4 Possessive adjectives vs pronouns (a)Incorrect: This is my one.Correct: This is mine. 10.5 Reflexive pronouns (a)Incorrect: Please contact me directly instead of contact my manager.Correct: Please contact me directly instead of contacting my manager.Incorrect: He blamed him for the mistake.Correct: He blamed himself for the mistake. 11. Relative clauses 11.1 Wrong relative pronoun (a)Incorrect: The people which live here are friendly.Correct: The people who live here are friendly. 11.2 Omission of necessary relative pronoun (a)Incorrect: The man I spoke to yesterday is my boss. (correct, but need detection of style?)Use clearer error:Incorrect: The man spoke to me yesterday is my boss.Correct: The man who spoke to me yesterday is my boss. 11.3 Non-defining vs defining comma use (b)Incorrect: My brother who lives in Canada is a doctor. (when only one brother)Correct: My brother, who lives in Canada, is a doctor. 11.4 Where vs which (a)Incorrect: The restaurant which we had dinner is closed.Correct: The restaurant where we had dinner is closed. 12. Word order 12.1 Adverb of frequency position (a)Incorrect: He goes usually to the gym after work.Correct: He usually goes to the gym after work. 12.2 Question inversion (a)Incorrect: You are free tomorrow?Correct: Are you free tomorrow? 12.3 Topic–comment order interference (a)Incorrect: This book I yesterday bought.Correct: I bought this book yesterday. 12.4 Mid-sentence adverb position (b)Incorrect: He quickly finished his very difficult homework. (acceptable but style)Correct: He finished his very difficult homework quickly. 13. Negation 13.1 Auxiliary do in negation (a)Incorrect: I no understand this part.Correct: I do not understand this part. 13.2 Double negatives (a)Incorrect: I don’t need no help.Correct: I don’t need any help. 13.3 Negative word order (a)Incorrect: I understand not what you mean.Correct: I do not understand what you mean. 14. Coordination and subordination 14.1 Comma splice (a)Incorrect: I finished the report, I sent it to you.Correct: I finished the report, and I sent it to you.Correct: I finished the report; I sent it to you. 14.2 Run-on sentences (a)Incorrect: The meeting was long we were all tired after that.Correct: The meeting was long, so we were all tired after that. 14.3 Sentence fragments (a)Incorrect: Because I was late.Correct: I was late because the traffic was heavy. 14.4 Overuse of and vs subordinator (b)Incorrect: I didn’t join and I was sick.Correct: I didn’t join because I was sick. 15. Comparatives and superlatives 15.1 Double comparative (a)Incorrect: This solution is more better.Correct: This solution is better. 15.2 Forming comparatives with long/short adjectives (a)Incorrect: This task is more easy.Correct: This task is easier. 15.3 Than vs as...as (a)Incorrect: He is more tall as me.Correct: He is taller than me. 15.4 Superlative with wrong article (a)Incorrect: She is most efficient person in our team.Correct: She is the most efficient person in our team. 16. Quantifiers and determiners 16.1 Few vs a few; little vs a little (a)Incorrect: We have few time to prepare.Correct: We have little time to prepare. 16.2 Too vs very (a)Incorrect: The meeting was too long and everyone enjoyed it.Correct: The meeting was very long and everyone enjoyed it. 16.3 Each vs every vs all (b)Incorrect: Each student must submit their assignments online. (debated; flag only)Correct: Every student must submit their assignments online. 16.4 Much vs many vs a lot of (a)Incorrect: There are much people in the lobby.Correct: There are many people in the lobby. 17. Adjectives and adverbs 17.1 Adjective vs adverb (a)Incorrect: He speaks very clear.Correct: He speaks very clearly. 17.2 Good vs well (a)Incorrect: She did the presentation very good.Correct: She did the presentation very well. 17.3 Position of evaluative adjectives (b)Incorrect: It’s a too difficult very long task.Correct: It’s a very long, too difficult task. 18. Voice (active/passive) 18.1 Passive formation (a)Incorrect: The document was sign by the manager.Correct: The document was signed by the manager. 18.2 Unnecessary passive in casual speech (b)Incorrect: The dinner was finished by us at 9 p.m.Correct: We finished dinner at 9 p.m. 19. Reported speech 19.1 Backshifting tense (b)Incorrect: He said he is busy.Correct: He said he was busy. 19.2 Pronoun and time reference shift (b)Incorrect: She told me she will come tomorrow.Correct: She told me she would come the next day. 20. Punctuation (core grammar-related) 20.1 Capitalization of I and proper nouns (a)Incorrect: i met mr chan in central.Correct: I met Mr Chan in Central. 20.2 Missing final period in sentences (a)Incorrect: Please see the attached reportCorrect: Please see the attached report. 20.3 Comma in lists (a)Incorrect: We bought chairs tables and computers.Correct: We bought chairs, tables and computers. 20.4 Apostrophes in possessives (a)Incorrect: The companys policy is strict.Correct: The company’s policy is strict. 20.5 Comma after introductory clause (b)Incorrect: After reviewing your application we decided to proceed.Correct: After reviewing your application, we decided to proceed. 21. Spelling-like grammar issues 21.1 Common homophones (a)Incorrect: I will send you the file latter.Correct: I will send you the file later. 21.2 Its vs it’s (a)Incorrect: The company changed it’s logo.Correct: The company changed its logo. 21.3 Their / there / they’re (a)Incorrect: There proposal was accepted.Correct: Their proposal was accepted. 22. Formal vs informal register (professional vs casual) 22.1 SMS-style abbreviations in professional context (b)Incorrect (professional email): Thx for your reply, I’ll get back ASAP.Correct (professional email): Thank you for your reply; I will get back to you as soon as possible. 22.2 Contractions in very formal documents (b)Incorrect: We can’t approve this request at the moment.Correct: We cannot approve this request at the moment. 22.3 Slang / colloquialisms in professional writing (b)Incorrect: The client was kind of pissed off.Correct: The client was rather upset. 22.4 Over-direct imperatives in professional emails (b)Incorrect: Send me the report by today.Correct: Please send me the report by the end of today. 23. Typical Cantonese–English transfer 23.1 “Add oil” and direct idiom transfer (a)Incorrect: Add oil in your exam!Correct: Good luck with your exam! 23.2 Overuse of “very” (a)Incorrect: This issue is very serious, please very pay attention.Correct: This issue is very serious, please pay close attention. 23.3 “Open/close the light” (a)Incorrect: Please open the light.Correct: Please turn on the light. 23.4 “Will be” for general facts (a)Incorrect: Hong Kong people will be very busy.Correct: Hong Kong people are very busy. 23.5 Drop of subject pronoun (a)Incorrect: Cannot join the meeting tomorrow.Correct: I cannot join the meeting tomorrow. 24. Collocations and word choice 24.1 Strong vs heavy (a)Incorrect: The coffee has a very heavy taste.Correct: The coffee has a very strong taste. 24.2 Make vs do (a)Incorrect: I need to do a decision soon.Correct: I need to make a decision soon. 24.3 High vs tall (a)Incorrect: The building is very high than the others.Correct: The building is much taller than the others. 24.4 Big vs large/major (b)Incorrect: This is a big problem in our company.Correct: This is a major problem in our company. 25. Discourse markers and cohesion 25.1 However/Therefore with correct punctuation (b)Incorrect: However we still have some concerns.Correct: However, we still have some concerns. 25.2 Also / too / as well positioning (b)Incorrect: Also I would like to ask a question.Correct: I would also like to ask a question. 25.3 Overuse of so in formal writing (b)Incorrect: The sales dropped, so we are worried.Correct: The sales dropped; therefore, we are concerned. 26. Email / letter conventions (professional) 26.1 Salutation format (b)Incorrect: Dear Mr. Chan,Correct: Dear Mr Chan, 26.2 Subject line capitalization and clarity (b)Incorrect: re: questionCorrect: Re: Question about Q4 Budget 26.3 Closing formula (b)Incorrect: Best Regards,Correct: Best regards, Would you like this expanded into a checklist specification (per error type) for implementation, or kept as this lean list of types + minimal pairs?
